UVic IEEE Student Branch Email

 

The UVic IEEE Student Branch presents this fall's series of SkillDev
Workshops! 

 

These workshops/presentations are meant to be overviews and introductions.
So even if you're not in electrical or software engineering, they're
wonderful learning opportunities to better your understanding of potential
directions you could take your degree through minors and specializations.

 

These events are independent and do not require you to attend prior events
to participate in later events!

 

Events

 

1.	Introduction to Modern Machine Learning (2pm-4pm, Sat November 13th
Zoom Online Meeting)

Students will be given a basic set of intuitions with just enough math for a
strong fundamental understanding of modern machine learning. Then students
will be brought through coded examples in Keras with Tensorflow to learn
some skills in real-world machine learning frameworks. The goal is to give
enough of a foundation to allow attendees to launch their own machine
learning projects!

 

2.	Introduction to Natural Language Processing (NLP) (6pm-8pm, Sat
November 20th, Zoom Online Meeting)

Learn about the applications and architecture of a Natural Language
Processing based chatbot, including technologies such as tokenization and
named entity recognition. Our guest speaker will present a coded example
demo with Google Colab which gives a foundation for attendees to build their
own NLP project.

 

3.	Introduction to Soldering (2pm-4pm, November 27th and 28th, ELW
B336)

Learn how to solder hands-on with real components. You'll learn proper
practices and safety as well as component mounting via through-hole
soldering and general use. This workshop is super useful for capstone
courses and ECE 299.

UVic IEEE Student Branch Email

 

The UVic IEEE Student Branch presents this fall’s series of SkillDev Workshops!

 

These workshops/presentations are meant to be overviews and introductions. So even if you're not in electrical or software engineering, they're wonderful learning opportunities to better your understanding of potential directions you could take your degree through minors and specializations.

 

These events are independent and do not require you to attend prior events to participate in later events!

 

Events

 

  1. Introduction to Modern Machine Learning (2pm-4pm, Sat November 13th  Zoom Online Meeting)

Students will be given a basic set of intuitions with just enough math for a strong fundamental understanding of modern machine learning. Then students will be brought through coded examples in Keras with Tensorflow to learn some skills in real-world machine learning frameworks. The goal is to give enough of a foundation to allow attendees to launch their own machine learning projects!

 

  1. Introduction to Natural Language Processing (NLP) (6pm-8pm, Sat November 20th, Zoom Online Meeting)

Learn about the applications and architecture of a Natural Language Processing based chatbot, including technologies such as tokenization and named entity recognition. Our guest speaker will present a coded example demo with Google Colab which gives a foundation for attendees to build their own NLP project.

 

  1. Introduction to Soldering (2pm-4pm, November 27th and 28th, ELW B336)

Learn how to solder hands-on with real components. You'll learn proper practices and safety as well as component mounting via through-hole soldering and general use. This workshop is super useful for capstone courses and ECE 299. 

 

REGISTER HERE

 

If you’re looking for a quiet space to study at one of our workstations or work on your projects, the IEEE Student Branch offers a maker space with a variety of tools such as oscilloscopes, function generators, soldering stations, spectrum analyzer, and more. It’s also a great place to work and meet other students in the faculty. If you’d like to join, click HERE.
